Award.AwardTitle: Enhancing Identifiability of Computer Simulation Models via Design for Calibration

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to develop a Design for Calibration (DfC) methodology for enhancing identifiability in simulation models. Identifiability refers to the difficulty in separating two general sources of uncertainty - parameter uncertainty and model uncertainty - in predictive modeling. Parameter uncertainty results from imperfect knowledge of the underlying physical parameters, and model uncertainty results from approximations and other inaccuracies in a simulation model. To ensure proper identifiability of these uncertainties when combining abundant simulation data with limited physical experimental data, the research takes advantage of two key enabling factors, the first being the inherently multi-response nature of computer simulations, and the second being the availability of extensive simulation results prior to designing the physical experiment. Using spatial random field modeling within a Bayesian framework, the methodology will determine the best subset of response variables to measure experimentally and the most efficient combination of input settings to use over the experiments, with the objective of optimally enhancing identifiability of the uncertainties.

If successful, the results of this research will help ensure identifiability of predictive uncertainties in a manner that allows limited experimental resources to be used most efficiently. This is critically important in simulation-based engineering and science across all engineering disciplines for many reasons that extend beyond achieving good myopic prediction. Learning and distinguishing the true physical parameters and simulation model inaccuracies has broad-reaching implications for i) new product/process designs that are much more complex than the experimental testbed, ii) improving future generations of simulation code, and iii) providing more accurate prediction over a wider set of input regions. Because the methodology is not tied to a particular type of simulation code or application domain, it is expected to be widely applicable. This work will leverage the broad-based constituency of the interdisciplinary doctoral Predictive Science and Engineering Design cluster at Northwestern, through which multidisciplinary testbed applications will be drawn and the results disseminated throughout different engineering domains.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The use of computer simulation to understand, design, and improve complex systems in manufacturing and many other fields of science and engineering is now commonplace. Two general sources of uncertainty that result in differences between the simulation model prediction and reality are parameter uncertainty and model uncertainty. The former results from imperfect knowledge of underlying physical parameters (e.g., various material properties in finite element simulation of a sheet metal stamping operation). The latter results from approximations and other inaccuracies in the simulation model that exist even if all parameters are known. A framework in which various response surfaces are represented as spatial random processes has emerged as the most popular model calibration method for combining (usually quite abundant) simulation data with (usually more limited) physical experimental data to improve model prediction in the face of these uncertainties. However, recent results indicate that accurate calibration, as the problem is typically formulated and implemented, is very difficult. Even though it may result in reasonably good myopic prediction of the responses at input combinations similar to those used in the experiments, it often fails at distinguishing between the effects of the different parameter and model uncertainties, which we refer to as non-identifiability. This research has created a Design for Calibration (DfC) methodology for enhancing identifiability in simulation models.

In creating the DfC methodology, this research was the first to take advantage of two key factors that have been overlooked in the prior literature, but that enable identifiability. The first is the inherently multi-response nature of most computer simulations, in which many different response variables (e.g., stress, strain, energy, deflection), at many different spatial locations (e.g., a stress field), and at many different points in time are automatically calculated and generally share a mutual dependence on the unknown parameters. The second enabling factor is the availability, prior to designing the physical experiment, of extensive simulation results that contain valuable information on the nature of the response surfaces.

Taking into account these two enabling factors, and with the goal of enhancing identifiability, the new DfC methodology determines i) the best small subset of response variables and spatial/temporal locations to measure experimentally, from the large set of responses that are generated in the simulations; and ii) efficient combination of input settings to use over the experiments (and over a further round of simulation, if deemed necessary). To achieve these challenging outcomes, this research used a Bayesian spatial random process framework to develop new methodologies for achieving the following building block outcomes: Evaluation of identifiability before observing the experimental data. Quantifying the impact of using multiple responses on improving identifiability. Gleaning insight into the characteristics that lead to identifiability and conveying this insight to designers. Computationally expensive but exact optimization of the best subset of responses. Computationally efficient approximate optimization of the best subset of responses using a surrogate preposterior analysis. Computationally efficient extensions to complex intercoupled multidisciplinary systems. Fast and numerically-stable spatial random process models for dense data. A new spatial random process model that is more effective for real physical systems.

According to the NSF Blue Ribbon Panel report, Simulation-Based Engineering and Science (SBE&S) is the “computational intelligence” needed to understand, predict, and ultimately design and/or control complex natural and man-made systems. This research has directly addressed one of the formidable challenges identified in the SBE&S blue ribbon panel report:  The unification of scientific computation and experimentation. Moreover, in a NSF sponsored workshop on uncertainty quantification (UQ) methodology, identifiability in experimental calibration of simulation models was designated an important problem for which there were no viable solutions at the time. By exploiting the two key enabling factors that have heretofore been overlooked, this DfC research has provided an identifiability solution that makes most efficient use of limited experimental resources to generate information and build knowledge of unknown modeling parameters and the model discrepancy. More broadly, this research has created a methodology for minimizing the resources required for physical experiments in prediction, which is anticipated to have a large societal impact via reducing the cost in scientific and research endeavors.
